title: British Developer Edo Mapelli Mozzi Says Luxury is About Authenticity—And Creating Spaces to Get Together
text:
Edo Mapelli Mozzi is a British property developer, and the founder and chief executive of Banda Property, a development and interior design company based in London.



The company is known for converting historic buildings and single-family houses, as well as building new construction from scratch. They also work on private home projects all over the world, including the Alps and Ibiza, where they often act more as interior architects and development partners with other companies, Mr. Mozzi said.



“We are the architect, developer and interior designer, so nothing falls between the gaps. By taking ownership of the project you have a more holistic approach,” he said.

More: Why a Miami Developer Says Now’s the Time for ‘Hopping on a Plane’ and Starting to Shop

Among their recent London projects is a 19th-century London beer bottling factory transformed into seven luxury duplex apartments, collectively dubbed the Richmond Brewery Stores, and 13-19 Leinster Square, a row of 19th-century townhouses—that later served as a three-star hotel—and now comprises 15 high-end homes.



And while he’s become well known in real estate circles in London, Mr. Mozzi, 35, also recently made headlines for his personal life—in September, it was announced that he and England’s Princess Beatrice of York are engaged.



We caught up with Mr. Mozzi to discuss the importance of flow in a home, why he pays attention to the details (like phone-charging stations) and more.

More: Architect Ricardo Álvarez-Díaz Is All About Sustainability and Resiliency

Mansion Global: How would you describe your dream property.

Edo Mapelli Mozzi: We always design homes that buyers want to live in, not just invest in. We’re always thinking about things like, “Will there be storage?” “Where are they going to plug in their phones?”



I like a large, usable space that’s logical. It’s wonderful when the master bedroom, kitchen, living and dining room face onto a garden square, as they do at Leinster Square.



You want a logical flow. You don’t want, for example, a master bedroom that shares a wall with another bedroom. You want every bedroom to have a guest water closet, and an adequate-sized utility room.



We do private projects for people all over the world, and we often do heritage buildings and make them modern. We’ll keep a facade that’s listed, but now it’s got new air conditioning, modern heating. And I love the mixture of old and new. You don’t want a home to feel like a show home. And you can mix that old and new with photography, paintings and furniture.

From Penta: Mark Rothko’s ‘Blue Over Red’ Could Top $25 Million

MG: What does luxury mean to you?

EMM: Time is a luxury, and so is human contact, and quality time with the people you care about is important. For us, it’s about creating space for that interaction to happen. We don’t have big plasma TVs everywhere, because we want to create connections.



Another important element of luxury is the story behind a property. It’s about the authenticity.



Why is a piece of art worth so much? Because of the story of the artist, and the authenticity of the piece. In our projects, we’ve hand-chosen the marble from the quarries, we’ve transported it, with thousands of people involved. We’ve chosen the trees that become the floors. Once you know the background of those individual elements, you know it’s luxury.



Many new developments are white boxes with nice amenities. We’ve tried to make our interiors very high level—we want the marble in the bathrooms and the kitchens to shine through.

More: Compass’s ‘Chief Evangelist’ on the Importance of a Home’s Context

MG: What’s the most important amenity to have in a home right now?

EMM: We’ve moved away from very expensive gyms and members clubs. The concierge is still there, though, because people want the security. People are still going to work every day and want their dogs walked, and their packages picked up. Having a gym in the basement or a swimming pool, or a wine club—all these tools that developers have used that act as an attraction to people buying off plan— are not used, and they just add to service charges.



I always see people in my gym who have gyms in their building. People don’t want to go to a dining space in the basement, they want to go to the cool, new restaurant around the corner. And they want to keep their service charges lower.



We do have some private gardens, and what those do is create a community. Inside the garden there are events that happen.



But people also want proximity to the big parks, like Hyde Park.



We’ve also seen a lot of simplicity when it comes to home automation and air conditioning and heating. The interface needs to be simple.

More: Sotheby’s International Realty Executive Says Customizing a Home is Key

MG: What area do you think is the next hub for luxury properties?

EMM: London is quite affordable for the international community, due to taxes, and the political uncertainty. The dollar-to-sterling conversion offers another 25% discount. What I always say is to look to the established locations. If you go to these “brand new” areas where there are 3,000 yo 5,000 new units being introduced at a time, they’re going to be quite expensive, and they don’t have that basic infrastructure yet— the parks, gardens, good transport, good schools.

We focus on Notting Hill, Chelsea and Battersea.

You’ve also got to know that you can sell a home before you buy it, so your life doesn’t get held up because you can’t sell your home.

More: Design Firm Chief Says Luxury is About Tapping Into All the Senses

MG: What’s the biggest surprise in the luxury real estate market right now?

EMM: There’s still a reasonable amount of activity, but I guess it’s the high-net-worth investors who are seeing the opportunities to get in. The last six months have really been a buyer’s market, and I’ve been surprised by a lot of interest. We recently finished a scheme in Chelsea, and we sold out in six months. Buyers have great choices.

Also, people are saying, “I have 5 million pounds, why don’t you show me what’s available.” People are more open to explore how far that money will go anywhere.

Transactions are down, though, because British buyers are in chains. They can’t sell, so they can’t buy. Those transactions are much slower.

But the overseas buyers love London.We’ve certainly got people who’ve lived in Hong Kong who are coming here. People come back to England for the schools.

More: Luxury is About Inner Wellness, Says Los Angeles-Based Designer

MG: What’s your best piece of real estate advice?

EMM: Make sure you buy something that stands the test of time. Get a good buying agent. Really understand the developer, the project and what’s going on behind the walls.

There are so many more buying agents in London now, and you need to have the right quality of advisors.

And you need to think about how your lifestyle might change in five-to-10 years. Transaction costs in London are about 10%, so you need to have plans in place.
